awd_abstract_narration:
Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) are an excellent cosmological probe, and observations of SNe Ia are particularly good at constraining the current cosmic expansion rate and the nature of dark energy. This project will address the following questions:  What is the expansion history of the Universe and what is driving the accelerated expansion? Is "dark energy" a cosmological constant, something more exotic, or do we need to re-evaluate our model of gravity? Is the "tension" between local and distant measurements of the Hubble constant caused by systematic errors, or does it point to new physics?  As part of this research, training will be provided to several graduate students and 12 community-college students in observational techniques.  Outreach will be undertaken through public lectures and the press, and the principle investigator will work with underrepresented students to transition from two-year colleges to four-year programs.  

The team will perform two low-redshift SNe Ia surveys to (1) reduce the largest source of systematic uncertainty in SN cosmology, the photometric calibration of the low-redshift SN sample, (2) further reduce other systematics related to dust reddening and SN physics, (3) cross-calibrate two of the world's best photometric systems on which 1250 cosmologically useful low-redshift SNe Ia will be observed, (4) produce the first sample of SNe Ia ranging from 0 < z < 0.8 observed with a single telescopic system, (5) obtain spectra of hundreds of SNe Ia, (6) examine potential distance improvements using spectral data, and (7) produce the tightest constraints on the nature of dark energy and current expansion rate of the Universe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our team has performed precise observations and analysis of Type Ia supernovae, a particular kind of exploding star, to understand the nature of dark energy.  Dark energy accounts for the majority of the mass-energy budget in the Universe and is causing the Universe's expansion to accelerate.  Understanding its nature is one of the biggest open questions in all of Physics.

We ran two separate observing surveys, the Swope Supernova Survey and the Young Supernova Experiment, discovering and following thousants of supernovae.  These detailed observations allow us to measure precise distances, with which we infer the expansion history of the Universe.

Our team performed analyses of a large number of supernovae to find ways to make supernovae even better distance indicators.  In particular, we found that the velocity of the supernova is related to its distance, and studies constraining cosmological information should correct for this effect.

We also studied special, individual supernovae to better understand the underlying physics of their progenitor star systems and how they explode.  Our most significant finding was that a supernova where we were monitoring it while it exploded was brighter in the first few days after explosion than expected.  There are several theories to explain this behavior, but no current theory can explain the full set of observations we obtained.

We built multiple software tools to analyze supernova data.

Through several studies, we constrained the dark energy equation-of-state parameter to be within 3% of -1, consistent with a cosmological constant.

This program has supported 35 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students, and 9 postdoctoral scholars.
